answers.answer: Hello,This may be due to iron deficiency anemia or megaloblastic anemia(caused by low B12).Have you started with iron and vit B 12 supplements?Other possibilities are diabetes,inner ear diseases,TIA(transient ischemic attacks)stroke,fibromyalgia and chronic fatigue syndrome which need to be ruled out.Blood sugar levels,ENT examination, ESR blood, rheumatoid factor, creatine kinase,electromyography and CT head can be helpful.Rapid loss is characteristic feature of chronic infections and malignancies.Pls discuss it with your husband’s doctor.Hope it helps.Take care and pls do keep me posted on how you are doing.

question: My husband had bilateral knee replacements 8 years ago, with fantastic results.  In April of 2007, he partially tore the ligament in his right knee but declined treatment.  In Feb. of this year he began having what he described as "charley horses",  in his right calf that became progressively more painful, eventually inhibiting his gait and developed an overwhelming fatigue and loss of appetite.  He had an ultrasound that ruled out blood clots.  A  7" long Bakers Cyst was found which was severely infected and by then had spread to the prosthesis in his right knee.  The cyst was surgically removed and the prosthesis removed with a spacer temporarily inserted. He was discharged to home with 7 weeks of I.V. Vancomycin.  A new prosthesis was placed and apparently has healed well.  The problem of most concern since then is that he continued to lose weight (approx. 60#) since March of this year; fatigue has continued; he is constantly complaining of feeling cold and achy.  In the past 2 months he has been experiencing momentary black out spells, usually upon standing from a sitting position or after walking a short distance. He notes a "bright light " just prior to the collapse.  He is slightly anemic: extremely low blood pressure, very pale and drawn.Diagnostics:  general blood work including TSH (normal even with history of partial thyroidectomy): RBC ( slight anemia): B-12 (low);CT scan of the abdomen (negative); endoscopy (small hiatal hernia); colonoscopy (scattered polyps- biopsy, negative/ diverticulitis):  CT of chest, pending.
title: concerned spouse
